WorkItem.Description:
Hello,

i want publish many 3rd Party Software through WSUSPackagePublisher into WSUS. But i only want to manage the 3rd Party Software in WSUS.MSC. For this i run after publishing in WUP a Query or a Trigger like this:

UPDATE [SUSDB].[dbo].[tbUpdate] SET [IsLocallyPublished] = 0 WHERE [IsLocallyPublished] <> 0

After running this Query, i can't see my published 3rd Party Software in WSUS Package Publisher. 

Pls make a Checkbox or another option to switch between Updates where SET [IsLocallyPublished] = 0 and Where SET = 1.

Thanks and Regards
Winfried Sonntag
WorkItem.Summary: Make Updates visible in WUP after SET IsLocallyPublished = 0

Comments.Message:
If I do that, WPP will show "Microsoft" updates. So creating an update will be EXTREMELY slow as WPP must build a list of all update to show potentially supersedes updates and prerequisites updates.
I need a way to differentiate Microsoft updates from locally published updates which have been mark as  not IsLocallyPublished.
Maybe an optional filter to filter out Vendor "Microsoft" will help to speed up a bit.

It is very useful to have all updates in WUP too. In WSUS-Konsole (like WSUS.MSC) i can approve, decline Updates and 3rd Party Software and run Reports. And it is possible to give other Admins only rights for read the status. 

But in WUP i need to 'see' the published 3rd Party Tools for update the 3rd Party Tools like Flash Player, Reader or Java Runtime.

Sorry, but in Local Update Publisher it is possible to see the Updates. I think you don't must read all updates at start, only i expand a node from treeview. Have a look on the picture, i attach this posting.

I see two options :
  
1- Read all updates and filtering out before importing in WPP, this will :

*       Show Locally Published Updates with IsLocallyPublish = 0
*       Show Locally Published Updates with IsLocallyPublish = 1
*       Hide Microsoft Updates (Office, Windows, Internet Explorer, Bing...)

In this case, if users publish Locally Updates with "Microsoft" as Vendor Name, these updates will be hide until they uncheck the option (if they have not change the IsLocallyPublish property). These 'False' Microsoft updates will appear in the 'Prerequisite' and the 'Supersedes' combobox only if they uncheck the option. Same thing for reports.
   
 2-  Read all updates and filtering out only when necessary in WPP, this will :

*       Show Locally Published Updates with IsLocallyPublish = 0
*       Show Locally Published Updates with IsLocallyPublish = 1
*       Show Microsoft Updates (Office, Windows, Internet Explorer, Bing...)

In this case, if users publish Locally Updates with "Microsoft" as Vendor Name, these updates will be __definitively__ hide. These 'False' Microsoft updates will __never__ appear in the 'Prerequisite' and the 'Supersedes' combobox. Same thing for reports.

I think, the option 1 is better for users and is simpler to code.

Did you see the LUP_View.png? There are 5 Microsoft Updates, 4 are for Office and 1 is User Profile CleanUp Service. These 5 Updates are NOT from Microsoft Update, i bring this Updates into the LUP. All other Microsoft Updates are from WSUS and coming from Microsoft Update direct. The other Update from Microsoft i see only i mark a checkbox: Show Microsoft Updates.

I vote for Option 1. If there is a EXE ready for testing, pls let me test in my environment.
I also vote for the first option.

I find a little bit strange thht there is 2 separates Vendor with the same name : 'Microsoft'.

OK, there is no Problem for me to write Microsoft Application and not Microsoft.
Maybe you can watch for 'Microsoft' and if is only 'Microsoft' in the Field filled, bring an Exeption and change 'Microsoft' to 'Microsoft Application 2 WUP'. ;)

Checking this checkbox will bring up your updates, but updates with 'Microsoft' as Vendor will still be hidden.

Yes, i have in my Test Lab a WSUS on a W2012 with external SQL Express 2012. But you can use in Windows Internal Database a query with SQLCMD:

```
sqlcmd -S np:\\.\pipe\MSSQL$MICROSOFT##SSEE\sql\query â€“i <scriptLocation>\IsLocallyPuplished.sql 
```
The IsLocallyPublished.sql contain this Code:
```
USE SUSDB; 
GO 
SET NOCOUNT ON; 
UPDATE [SUSDB].[dbo].[tbUpdate]
SET [IsLocallyPublished] = 'False' 
WHERE [IsLocallyPublished] = 'True'
```
